conclusion: Understanding the problem involves finding the temperature at state C using a p-V diagram.
State A is at 3 × 10^5 Pa and 2 × 10^-3 m³.
State B is at 2 × 10^5 Pa and 2 × 10^-3 m³.
State C is at 2 × 10^5 Pa and 3 × 10^-3 m³.
From A to B, pressure decreases but volume stays the same; from B to C, volume increases while pressure remains constant.
Using the ideal gas law PV = nRT, where n is constant.
Set up a ratio using the ideal gas law to find temperature at state C.
Calculate (PA * VA) / (PC * VC) = TA / TC and simplify to find TA = TC.
Realize TA = TC implies temperature at state C is 27°C.
Consider the process from A to B to C might affect temperature.
From A to B: Isochoric process, PA / PB = TA / TB, calculate TB = 200 K.
From B to C: Isobaric process, VB / VC = TB / TC, calculate TC = 300 K.
